{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562409,"name":"","username":"Iacon0","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/74df32/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T22:48:41.723Z","cooked":"

I’m a programming mentor for a team and our swerve drive works great except its odometery always overestimates how much it’s actually moved causing it to undershoot its pathplanner autos. We’re using a version of https://github.com/dirtbikerxz/basetwlonfxswerve as our swerve code and we’re using the correct max speed, gear ratio, and wheel diameter for our mk4is (4 inch diameter, L3 gears, and 5.2 m/s max speed thanks to krakens). I’m at my wit’s end as to why it thinks it’s moved ~20% more than it actually has.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":3,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T22:48:41.723Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":37.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496268,"topic_slug":"swerve-odometery-too-fast","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/dirtbikerxz/basetwlonfxswerve","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64414,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-odometery-too-fast/496268/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3562410,"name":"Tinnittin","username":"Tinnittin","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tinnittin/{size}/148604_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T22:52:57.337Z","cooked":"

How consistent is the overestimation? Try driving the robot in a straight line and record the actual distance traveled vs the estimated distance a few times over different distances. If it seems like it is exactly the same percentage off, there is likely some issue with your gear ratio, wheel diameter, or encoder pulses.

What wheels are you using? Could they have worn down or compress to a smaller diameter than 4 inches?

Opinions are my own."},"post_url":"/t/swerve-odometery-too-fast/496268/2","custom_user_title":"2046 Mentor. Opinions are my own.","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3562416,"name":"Ryan Reed","username":"Ryan_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_reed/{size}/268514_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T22:59:56.107Z","cooked":"

Your wheels might be slipping on acceleration.

Try comparing the error at very slow speeds (no slip) vs at the speed you were testing. If those have similar error, it’s likely the ratio/diameter. You can measure the actual diameter of the wheels with calipers, as the tread might be pretty worn. You can also validate the ratio used on the swerve assemblies by turning the wheels and verifying that the change in encoder position agrees with your ratios. Check that for all wheels, someone may have used the wrong gears on some of them.

If the slow speed test is accurate, then the discrepancy is due to slipping. You should be able to see the slipping when looking at motor current. You can reduce drive motor current limits until it no longer slips (and improve your efficiency while you’re at it).
